paper: OVA-LP_ A Simple and Efficient Framework for Federated Learning on Non-IID Data

differences.summary: Abstract vs main text mismatch on 10.1%/34.5% baseline mapping
differences.why_impacts_score: Undermines trust and clarity of reported results

evidence.baseline_quote: versus much lower figures for FFT-MoE and PFPT (Fig. 4, Table 1).
evidence.final_quote: Abstract assigns 10.1%/34.5% to PFPT/FFT-MoE; main text maps 10.1% to FFT-MoE.

differences.summary: Acc@95 metric undefined, causing evaluation ambiguity
differences.why_impacts_score: Creates ambiguity in how convergence/cost are interpreted

evidence.baseline_quote: several figures emphasize R(50) without consistent absolute accuracy reporting in the main text
evidence.final_quote: Acc@95 is not explicitly defined in the evaluation protocol (Sec. 4.1), creating ambiguity.

differences.summary: Clarity score lowered due to undefined metric and reporting mismatch
differences.why_impacts_score: New reporting issues lead to reduced clarity assessment

evidence.baseline_quote: Clarity (10): 8 — The paper is well-written with clear equations and figures
evidence.final_quote: Clarity (10): 7 — Acc@95 is undefined, and the Abstract reverses the 10.1%/34.5% mapping

differences.summary: Contradictory convergence example (LP-Softmax Acc@95 vs R(50))
differences.why_impacts_score: Signals possible metric misuse and unreliable reporting

evidence.baseline_quote: OvA-LP reaches Acc@95 in 1–3 rounds under full participation (Appendix A.1, Table 3)
evidence.final_quote: LP-Softmax Non-IID reports Acc@95 ‘27 ± 9’ rounds while R(50)=56.3% suggests it never approaches 95%
